ratings.comment: Going to Prof Gammie's lectures is like consuming his puke to determine what he ate for breakfast. Messy slides. I think his material was interesting, he probably just found it difficult to teach it in introductory level. I did not like how he explained things outside of lectures - it never really gave me an answer.

I personally did not like having him as a professor. His lectures were very unclear about what we needed to know. He threw up large diagrams and said we only needed to parts of it but didn't actually say which parts, and then proceeded to explain the whole diagram. He expects you to have already learned all the content before in other classes.

I did NOT like Stephen. He was not clear on what he wanted us to know, even after being explicitly asked by a student. He included examples for concepts that were interesting but did not apply to the exam whatsoever and his explanations for things that we actually needed to know were very vague so I kind of taught myself a lot of the concepts :(

Pretty good lecturer, clearly cares about what he is teaching and has a passion for it. Lectures are a little slow sometimes, but overall really enjoyed learning about the content. Exams based on lecture alone, but textbook and outside materials were definitely helpful in studying. Would probably take class from him again.

He is clearly very intelligent and loves what he does, the lectures were just boring and mostly pictures. The 3rd exam was very specific, practically needed to memorize word for word the slides. Little much for a gen bio class and not an upper level physiology course. Overall, not my favorite 151 professor.

Dr. Gammie is very kind and wants you to learn the content! His lectures were a bit lack-luster, though. It was difficult to know what he wants you to know come exam time as he does give you so much content in the third 151 section- beware that it's the hardest section! But the content was interesting and his tests were fair.

Prof Gammie was by far the better of the two professors for this class. His lectures are clear and highlights what's important to know. His exams are verbatim what you see on his lectures/study guides. Literally only studied using the study guides for each lecture and got A's on his exams.

Dr. Gammie, is extremely smart; however, his lectures are lackluster and breeze through things in a form that expects students to have their PhDs. He talks at like 1000 miles per hour and does not really slow down to explain things. Not bad, just needs improvement as to his teaching abilities.

Professor Gammie thrives in teaching this course. He is truly passionate and guiding the students to find their interests and passions. He gives us the tools we need and is willing to meet to answer questions at any time. I loved this course and highly recommend it to any Neuroscience student. It consists of 4 homework and a project of your choice!

A-student, brief email correspondences with Professor. 3/5 teaching. Lectures lack transitions, overviews, and are unclear at times. Lacking overview makes understanding big picture difficult. Read textbook for comprehension. Yellow text on slides are important for exams. Hospitable and encouraging person. Consultant role more then professor.

Great professor. To do well, don't lag behind, understand that he goes fast. All lectures are recorded which helps a lot. Concepts can be difficult so really understand the material. It is nearly impossible to start studying for exams a few days before and do well. Give yourself adequate leeway time for studying.

I like him a lot as a person. If you go to office hours, he is very kind and really not that judgy. What bothers me immensely is his lecture style, his pace, and his slides. Long story short: he should not be lecturing. He moves 574003 mph for difficult concepts, packs his slides with more words than the syllabus, and does not clear things up.

Stephen is a great guy, but after our first exam went well (very high average) he made the next exam way tougher. His exams are based primarily off of lecture material but GET THE BOOK. It makes far more sense to read it on paper. Lectures are recorded. By the way, anything in highlighted yellow text is probably the focus of an exam question.

Professor Gammie is one of the worst lecturers I've ever seen. His slides were a mess, and his explanations were fast and incoherent. He ended every lecture 15 minutes early instead of slowing down and actually explaining the concepts he wanted understood. There was virtually no way to practice for the exams, which are most of your grade. Horrible.

Gammie's lectures are a bit hard to follow. He likes to go off of his lecture slides and go to various other websites. He has a lot of pictures and charts, most of which aren't required for the exam. He likes in-lecture participation, although it's not required. Highly recommend reading the required readings, they helped a lot.

Dr. Gammie is a great professor, but sometimes moves quickly in lecture. It is sometimes difficult to know exactly what material you need to know for the exam. Do the SimBio, go prepared to discussion, and learn the material as you go (don't try to cram his material). PLA and the study guides are also very helpful if you really want to get an A.

Gammie is passionate but lectures can move fast, and it is sometimes unclear what material is important for the exam. He tries hard to encourage participation even in a large class to help students engage in the material. He also is very approachable and will take questions. Although grading criteria was a little unclear, the exam was fair.

Lectures are confusing. Even asking questions during office hours, he doesn't give straight up answers but instead likes to answer questions in a roundabout way. Overall, nice guy and very knowledgeable, but difficult to access the knowledge that you are looking for.

It was bad.  The lectures did not make much sense and went extremely fast.  I was excited to have a  the 200 question study guide for the 50 question test and found that the test was still really difficult and the questions were difficult (so many which of these statements are false questions) find another class if possible.

Stephen is a great guy and a very good professor.  Lectures are interesting but cover a lot of material.  I just reviewed the lecture slides after class and was good to go.  He sends out a study guide which is long and tedious but I recommend it because most test questions came from his study guide.  Definitely recommend him as a professor
Gammie is a awesome lecturer. Does a great job making the class interesting, and you learn a lot. Exam questions are straight off his study guide so just make sure to put in the work before the test.

This professor is awesome. Do the study guide. 80%-90 of the questions come from there. It was really long, but helpful. He speaks quite fast, so better read book before going to the lecture. Refer to the powerpoint. That is where all the test questions come from. He was willing to help students.
He certainly knows what he's talking about. Go to lecture, that's where he gets his exam questions from and also do the review packet(s) because they were very helpful. His exam was very fair.
Makes lectures interesting and funny, and gives out a review sheet for the exam that was long but helpful.

a lot of info. on exams comes from powerpoints. makes lectures clear and interesting. sends out exam study guides that are long but a good review. straight forward questions on exam. got an A without much effort.
He's a great professor and makes animal phys very interesting.  Pay attention to pictures/diagrams that he references.  Loved his powerpoints too.
Makes material very interesting. Explanations are ok, good to read the textbook for better understanding. Gives extra material that is not in the textbook so better go for lectures.

great teacher, starts off with science news so actually get to see whats going on in the world of science. Animal physiology is tricky, but his test was reasonable...nothing tricky, but a lot of memorization. Loved his sense of humor, and was very willing to answer questions
great prof.
